Deidentified_article_title: Here's What Happens When [ORGANIZATION], Not Police, [ORGANIZATION]
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Ultimately, she was directed to someone at [ORGANIZATION] who said she would pay the site a visit. But every time the ORG1 worker came by, the homeless people had already moved on, only to come back later. Shes never been able to make contact with them because by the time she comes out, theyre gone, [ORGANIZATION] said. It would definitely help if there were someone who could respond quicker. Theyd reach them and be able to have a dialogue. Police are often called on to address complaints about homelessness and mental illness.[PERSON] lacks a crisis response team that can be dispatched immediately to address mental health crises and behavioral health issues. Instead, the task often falls to a patchwork of social services providers whose work is supported by temporary grants. Or to [ORGANIZATION] police officers, most of whom are not trained in crisis intervention or de-escalation for the mentally ill. Behavioral health calls make up 10 to 30 of ORG9s call volume, the department said. A growing number of American cities are embracing another [STREET] sending mental health first responders instead of police. The teams are made up of unarmed crisis workers, such as social workers and health care personnel, who advocates say are better equipped than police to handle cases that dont involve violence or crime. The concept was pioneered in [ORGANIZATION], [ORGANIZATION], [ORGANIZATION]. ORG2 - or ORG3 - is embedded in the areas 911 system. Dispatchers who receive calls about mental health crises, homelessness, substance abuse and other welfare checks direct the information to ORG2. On a fundamental level, the ORG2 program is designed to send the right kind of first responders into emergent crisis situations where theres not a crime being committed, theres no medical emergency, no fire to be put out, but where there is still somebody whos in profound need, said [ORGANIZATION], the consulting director of [ORGANIZATION], which runs ORG21. ORG2 team members help deescalate conflict, refer individuals to services and even transport them to shelters, stabilization sites or medical clinics - avoiding unnecessary stays in jail or the emergency room, [ORGANIZATION] said. Outreach workers in [ORGANIZATION] are not embedded into the 911 system. In [ORGANIZATION], [ORGANIZATION], theyre treated like other first responders.Courtesy oF PERSON4 The program handles about 17 of the [ORGANIZATION] Police Departments call volume [LOCATION], which saves the [INSTITUTION] an estimated 8.5 million DATE2, according to [ORGANIZATION]. ORG2 budget is only 2.1 million. The team can always call for backup if workers need police assistance - theyre on the police radio system - but those occasions are rare. Of the 24,000 calls ORG2 responded to in [LOCATION], only 360, or 1.5, required police backup, [ORGANIZATION] said. Half of those cases only required police to conduct an involuntary psychiatric hold. Interaction with ORG2 is voluntary, [ORGANIZATION] said. We enter into our interactions with community members on a foundation of mutual trust and with an objective of the least intervention necessary to find immediate de-escalation and stabilization, [ORGANIZATION] said. Thats different from an officer who was trained through the academy, and this mentality is ingrained in them as a patrol officer, that they are a warrior and that they need to assume that every interaction they have with a community member could potentially become fatal, and to assumethat it will become violent and potentially fatal. Cities across the country are increasingly adopting the ORG2 model2. It has gained particular momentum in [DATE] as protests nationwide have called for police reform, including shifting police responsibilities and resources toward social services agencies. [PERSON] recently started sending personnel from its health and fire departments to behavioral health crises in lieu of police. GPE4 announced [PERSON] that it plans to pilot the concept in [ORGANIZATION] and East [ORGANIZATION], areas that produce the most mental-health related emergency calls. ORG6 started a similar program [ORGANIZATION]. Around the same time, [PERSON], GPE6 a new city department to pursue the idea. GPE7, Florida7launched its mental health team [PERSON], as did [PERSON], [ORGANIZATION]8. Theres even federal legislation9 aimed at helping states adopt the ORG2 model, introduced by senators from [ORGANIZATION] and [ORGANIZATION]0, and legislators are working to include a pared down version of that bill in the upcoming COVID-19 relief package10. Several mental health advocates in [ORGANIZATION] told ORG7 its a concept the city should consider. People who are having mental health problems are generally not criminals, said PERSON5, a longtime advocate for mental health and people experiencing homelessness. While they may be breaking some kind of misdemeanors, being a nuisance or behaving oddly, theyre generally not committing crimes. But their behavior can be very disconcerting and unpleasant. But thats not the kind of thing police are really trained to handle. Thats not what their job description is.They Have The Skills [ORGANIZATION] Police Chief [PERSON] is open to the idea of handing some police responsibilities to social workers. Following [ORGANIZATION] Lives Matter protests DATE8, the chief said at a press conference she agreed with activists that society relies too much on the police to address social ills. ORG9 should not be the primary respondents to matters involving homelessness and mental illness, she said. [ORGANIZATION] [INSTITUTION] Chief [PERSON] has lamented the fact that handling homelessness and mental illness has become a police responsibility.[PERSON] Those are all social issues that should be handled elsewhere, she said. Unfortunately when nobody else steps up, and there is nowhere else to turn to, people always turn to the police to take care of whatever the problem is. [ORGANIZATION] said she would much prefer social workers to take homelessness and mental illness off her departments plate. I think it would be fantastic because they have the skills, she said. [ORGANIZATION] declined to be interviewed for this story. In a statement, she said ORG9 has advocated for the involvement of social services providers and the department is open to finding alternate ways of responding to scenes. While we have looked at the programs being used in other cities and reached out to different agencies, we are not starting our own program at this time due to the pandemic and fiscal constraints, she said. However, replacing police with unarmed crisis responders has the potential to save money, according to ORG2. Beyond reducing the police departments call volume, [ORGANIZATION] estimates it saved over 14 million for ambulance rides and emergency room visits in DATE9. [ORGANIZATION] started training officers in crisis intervention11 in [LOCATION]0, but only 58 officers have completed the training so far, according to the departments latest strategic planning update. The pandemic interrupted an effort to train more officers, the department said. The department also runs the [ORGANIZATION] program, which pairs officers with homeless outreach workers to help connect unsheltered people to services.Could [ORGANIZATION] Adopt This Model?Police responses to mental and behavioral health callscan sometimes devolve into violence or even death. Mental health cases make up 13 of use-of-force incidents, according to the [ORGANIZATION] Police Departments latest force report12. And in [LOCATION]0, incidents in which island police injured or killed a person in mental distress have made headlines. [ORGANIZATION] lacks stabilization beds and affordable housing.[PERSON] That includes a [ORGANIZATION]1 man with schizophrenia who was killed by police in [LOCATION]1, a man on methamphetamine who died in [LOCATION]2 14after officers pepper-sprayed him and shot him with a [ORGANIZATION] and a man who suffered from paranoia killed by police in [LOCATION]3 after he allegedly threatened officers with a knife. Even in a ORG2 model, police would still need to respond to situations involving a weapon or aggressive behavior, but [ORGANIZATION] said crisis workers do sometimes respond in tandem with police to help with deescalation. In [ORGANIZATION]2, [ORGANIZATION]3, which started a modified version of ORG2 DATE8, the crisis workers respond alongside police officers. That collaboration is important for the safety of the mental health responders, according to [LOCATION], the countys emergency medical services director. My concern is everyone is jumping on the bandwagon of trying to take PD out of this equation, and there will be people who will get hurt who work for me, he said. Some mental health advocates in [ORGANIZATION] also expressed support for the ORG2 concept but were concerned about crisis responder safety. Its definitely a good option to explore, said [ORGANIZATION], a former ORG9 psychologist who is now in private practice. The hard thing is it can go from zero to 60 really quick and a crisis worker isnt comfortable with that. Another challenge in [ORGANIZATION] is the lack of stabilization facilities and affordable housing for people in crisis, according to several advocates. So even if crisis workers were able to calm people down and get them to accept help, there are few places to bring them for long-term care. We dont have anywhere to take them, said PERSON10, executive director of ORG13. There really are no stabilization beds. There really is no [STREET] for them to go If we dont have a stabilization center, we cant really do this project. ORG2 strength is in being a facilitator for people in crisis, [ORGANIZATION] said. But without a [STREET] to bring people that will address their needs, the program would fail. The only reason that ORG2 is as successful as we are keeping folks away from jail or out of the hospital is because we have a network of other resources in our community to rely on, [ORGANIZATION] said. If we didnt have those other resources available, we would just be helping cycle people through the hospital, and folks would still be going to jail. If a community like [ORGANIZATION] is really considering mobile crisis response inspired by ORG2, there also really needs to be an evaluation of what resources are lacking in the community for folks in crisis. Deidentified_article_title: [ORGANIZATION] will start housing the homeless in tiny pods in people's backyards
Deidentified_paragraph_text: The program, created by advocacy organization [ORGANIZATION] in partnership with students from [ORGANIZATION], will house the homeless in tiny pods in the backyards of willing homeowners. As reported by ORG2, the city will pilot the project [ORGANIZATION] with four homeless families in [ORGANIZATION], [PERSON]. Approximately 200 homeowners have expressed interest in putting pods in their backyards. Those who live in the pods will pay a limited amount of rent, and will receive social services that the county provides to homeless families it houses. PERSON0 and [ORGANIZATION], GPE2 residents who are considering putting a pod in their backyard, told5 the [PERSON] they understand the effects of rising rents in the city. Theyll cost 75,000 each and be financed by a combination of local government funds and private donations. The pods will be able to house one adult and two children  inside, there will be a bed some have bunk beds, shelves, a toilet, and a desk. Theyll all come with heat and full plumbing. Residents of a GPE2 neighborhood called [PERSON] a similar pilot project in [LOCATION]. The 96-square-foot backyard pods, created by the same students, will serve as homes for 14 homeless women. Deidentified_paragraph_text: DATE0 ORG0 by [PERSON] The alleys of [ORGANIZATION], [PERSON], are strewnwith piles of garbage and used drug needles, reflecting a growing problem ofhomelessness, drug addiction, and mental illness. Mental illness is [LOCATION] more common among thehomeless in [PERSON] than in any other state. According to a study from [ORGANIZATION], 35-401of homeless adults in [PERSON] suffer from some form of mental illness. The problem is apparent along FAC0, a popular biking trail on the east side of [ORGANIZATION] thatis cherished as peaceful slice of nature hidden from the urban sprawl.

Deidentified_article_title: Why [ORGANIZATION]'s [PERSON] Is the Worst in the Nation
Deidentified_paragraph_text: In [ORGANIZATION], a shantytown alongside a two-mile stretch of the corridor was the largest homeless encampment in the [ORGANIZATION]. It contained nearly 200 tents and an estimated 500 homeless people. In [LOCATION] since, criminal activity has become a routine occurrence. For example, in [DATE], police arrested a homeless woman for attempting to kidnap a [ORGANIZATION] girl playing near the trail. [PERSON], a shooting occurred. DATE5, an assailant stabbed a man in the arm before fleeing back into the sea of tents. Unfortunately, [ORGANIZATION] is no exception in [ORGANIZATION] it is a microcosm of [PERSON] largest city. In [ORGANIZATION], [ORGANIZATION] was home to an estimated 14,000 chronically homeless people, the vast majority of whom were in [ORGANIZATION], according to [ORGANIZATION]. The [ORGANIZATION] [INSTITUTION] has noofficial policy on clearing out the camps or relocating homeless individuals.Third parties now shoulder the burden of coordinating with the city andobtaining police protection in cleaning up the camps. Local officials claim to be pursuingsolutions, but the solutions offered thus far affordable-housingbonds4 and refusing to enforce prohibitions on camping on public rights of [STREET] and in city parks donothing to address the lack of mental-health treatment and drug-abuse problemsat the root of this humanitarian crisis. Nor is this a recent phenomenon. The neglectspans [PERSON]. GPE2 first opened the doors of ORG2 in DATE8 with the aim of treating those afflicted with mentalillness. The facility was meant to relieve overcrowding at the larger statehospital in [PERSON]. More and more individuals flooded into theasylum, and by [PERSON], the newer hospital had also exceeded capacity. Theovercrowding, combined with widespread abuse toward patients, worsened. Rather than reform the mental-healthtreatment system, the state simply closed FAC0 in [LOCATION]0, releasing thepatients ill-equipped to function independently onto the streets of [ORGANIZATION]. [LOCATION]1, the homeless, many of whom are addicted to drugs, remain on thestreets in the same abhorrent conditions.In [ORGANIZATION] alone, [ORGANIZATION] police seized about284 pounds of heroin and [LOCATION]. But those who are afflictedby addiction often never have to confront their habit, at least not due tolegal consequences. [PERSON] drug policy is defined by leniency.Police have neither the resources, nor the backing of their superiors to arrest6an individual for being on drugs in public or for having drugs on their person.In practice, heroin and [LOCATION] are legal. That isnt humane. Its gross governmental dereliction of duty. Resolving the homelessness crisis requires us to acknowledge the humanity of those afflicted. They are not human refuse they are people, albeit badly broken. But fixing the problem requires more than just a token verbal acknowledgment. Part of recognizing their humanity is understanding that the homeless are not merely victims of circumstance. They need help taking the first steps toward reclaiming their lives. The situation has gotten so bad that it nowdemands aggressive action at both the city and state levels. The police must beempowered to disperse these camps. Courts should require those in violation ofdrug laws to seek treatment. Community detox centers in [ORGANIZATION] shouldbecome core to the solution. These centers already offer the homeless trainingin job and social skills. These locally based organizations directly target drugand mental illness issues, but they are underutilized because the city has turneda blind eye to illicit-drug use and continues to tolerate [STREET] camping. Another key part of the solution is to give renewed focus to mental health treatment. Sometimes, that may require at least a temporary respite from independent living. Both the general population and the homeless are put at risk by the current situation. To better serve these individuals, we must remove the stigma surrounding mental-health treatment and replace it with understanding. That may be the only hope for these individuals to regain safe, productive lives. The post Why [ORGANIZATION]s Homeless Problem Is the Worst in the Nation7 appeared first on [ORGANIZATION]. By [ORGANIZATION], Assistant Professor of [ORGANIZATION] and Criminology, [ORGANIZATION] and PERSON1, Clinical Instructor of [ORGANIZATION] and Criminology, [ORGANIZATION]. Originally published at [ORGANIZATION] talks over police reform ended with no agreement2 on [ORGANIZATION], with ORG2 Democrats and Republicans blaming each other for the lack of progress. It isnt the first time that reform at a federal [ORGANIZATION] has been attempted - nor the first time it has [PERSON]. The sticking [ORGANIZATION] this time appear to be centered around proposed changes to use-of-force procedures and plans to strip officers of qualified [ORGANIZATION], which shields them from being sued. As scholars of criminal justice7 - one a former police officer of [ORGANIZATION] - we were not surprised by the collapse of bipartisan talks. Policing in the [ORGANIZATION] is politicized, making it harder to reach consensus in an age of polarization, even though most Americans believe that major [PERSON] are needed. In determining the magnitude of this failure, it is important to keep in mind that policing in the [ORGANIZATION] is inherently local. Community confidence is critical to police reform and community safety42. When citizens view police as legitimate and trustworthy, they are more likely to report crimes, cooperate during police investigations, comply with directives and work with police to find solutions to crime. ORG13 Efforts like those in [LOCATION] that put community engagement at the heart of police reforms undoubtedly are strides in the right direction. But they can go only so far. A noticeable shortcoming in most police reform programs is a focus on what is the right thing to do during confrontations with the public, rather than on trying to avert those situations in the first [STREET]. Deidentified_paragraph_text: The size and number of homeless camps in the city increased during the [ORGANIZATION] pandemic, [ORGANIZATION] to [ORGANIZATION]. Officials did not remove any camps from [ORGANIZATION], then picked up operations in a limited capacity, targeting areas where the biggest health and safety risks2 were identified in accordance with [PERSON] and local guidelines. Officials removed around 50 campsites a week before the onset of the [ORGANIZATION] pandemic, [ORGANIZATION] reported. With reduced operations over [LOCATION], officials have removed an average of five sites a week. Campsites are targeted if they are causing an excess of trash including needles and other biohazardous waste like untreated sewage scattered across [ORGANIZATION]. Despite campsites growing, officials arent sure if more people are homeless than at the start of the [ORGANIZATION] pandemic, according to [ORGANIZATION]. Officials say it could take [DATE] to clean up the encampments and trash to a pre-pandemic level. Around 30 campsite locations have more than 10 structures, up from four or five spots [ORGANIZATION], [ORGANIZATION] reported. The number of campsites that score higher than 70 on the citys ORG2 100-point risk assessment scale has up by 20 locations. Officials with [ORGANIZATION] reported record-breaking numbers of trash collection from campsites during the pandemic, according to [ORGANIZATION]. Over 818,500 pounds of trash was removed from campsites in [DATE], compared with 650,000 pounds during the same time in DATE5. We recognize the challenging work done by [ORGANIZATION] to respect individuals experiencing houselessness while also maintaining safe and hygienic conditions, and are extremely grateful for the thoughtfulness and compassion they bring to their work, Democratic [ORGANIZATION] Mayor [ORGANIZATION] said in a joint statement with [ORGANIZATION] Commissioners, [ORGANIZATION] reported. Deidentified_paragraph_text: So, when the local [ORGANIZATION] throws the entire stores perishables in the trash because they lost power, it garners the attention of the hungry, as well as those who wish to feed the hungry. According to reports, the [ORGANIZATION] story on [ORGANIZATION] in [ORGANIZATION] lost power on [ORGANIZATION] and threw away thousands of food items they say were no longer safe for consumption due to the temperatures the items had reached. The decision was made out of an abundance of caution, according to a [ORGANIZATION] spokesperson. To be clear, the food was not expired and was actually preserved outside due to the cold temperatures and many people were more than willing to take it regardless of the warning from [ORGANIZATION]. When someone spotted the food, they posted it on social media and individuals, hungry and helpful alike, descended on the [ORGANIZATION] dumpster.go snag some free food if you can get to the [ORGANIZATION] [ORGANIZATION] in [ORGANIZATION] yall [URL]Fv86mvNWrB3 PERSON0 mr1mportant DATE1 [ORGANIZATION] [TIME], the group of people around the dumpster collecting the food were quickly met by police officers. According to police, an employee called because they felt the situation was escalating and feared there may be a physical confrontation. A [ORGANIZATION] spokesperson sent the following [PERSON] in regard to the incident We appreciate people speaking out against hunger. We get it, throwing away food is never a good thing. Unfortunately, some perishable food that requires refrigeration at our [ORGANIZATION] store was out of temperature for a protracted period of time. This was due to a weather-related power outage and it is not safe for consumption. Out of an abundance of caution, we are disposing of the product to keep people safe. We engaged law enforcement, as the safety of our associates and customers is always our top priority. .comgold-guideActivist-Post-Recommended-Gold-IRA-Dealer-Cerified-Gold-Exchange.htmlBut these folks were hungry and were willing to get food from a dumpster. Cheese, pickles, yogurt things that are intentionally cultured and cured. Here its not broken windows, its tossed away but otherwise completely fine food, that person said. Its not a bad situation or vandalism, its literally the exact opposite feeding hungry people. Yet they still use the same apparatus to prevent anything from being done. Luckily, the police eventually left after realizing that there was no legitimate threat to person or property. The people returned and were able to get the food without incident, illustrating the unnecessary show of force in the first [STREET]. Further research and verification are left to the reader. 1 2DATE5[PERSON][PHONE][PERSON][PHONE]1819DATE[PERSON]2222[LOCATION]DATE52[PERSON][PHONE]031DATE[DATE]DATE5235[PERSON][PHONE]424DATE5244546 [DATE] 4950515[PERSON][PHONE]58596061 62 63 [DATE] 676869DATE59 [DATE] [PHONE]899091 92 Breaking [ORGANIZATION] Wants to Immediately Sign Stand-Alone Bill for 1,200 Stimulus Checks93 President [PERSON] said in a tweet [ORGANIZATION] night that he is willing to sign a stand alone bill authorizing stimulus check payments of 1,200 for [ORGANIZATION]n citizens if the [PERSON]3G9 can deliver such a bill to his [DATE] Things That You Must Believe in Order to Convince Yourself That Everything is Going to Turn Out Okay Somehow95 Despite everything that we have already been through in [ORGANIZATION], the dominant narrative in our society right now is that everything is going to be just fine once we get past our temporary problems. So many people that I hear from cant understand why I am so negative about the future, because they are completely convinced that really great [LOCATION] are just around the corner. As odd as this may sound, we are seeing this sort of wild optimism among both Democrats and Republicans, Christians and atheists, capitalists and communists. Of course about half the country will have their optimistic hopes for the future brutally crushed by the results of the upcoming election, but we arent there yet. For now, both sides are absolutely convinced that they are going to win, and both sides are envisioning a wonderful new era for our nation in which their values reign triumphant. If only things were that easy. The truth is that many of our largest problems have been steadily growing for DATE2, and they arent going to magically disappear just because a particular candidate wins an election. Our debt levels are absolutely exploding, our economy has plunged into a depression, there is widespread civil unrest in our streets, our nation is more divided than it has ever been in my entire lifetime, and our society is literally coming apart at the seams as just about every form of evil that you can possibly imagine is growing rapidly all around us. Deidentified_paragraph_text: Historic and ongoing systemic racism has left families of color more vulnerable going into the [ORGANIZATION] housing crisis, and that crisis, and the inadequate response to it, left them even worse off. Black and Hispanic communities lost over 1 trillion during the Great Recession that was never regained because the help came too late and well after foreclosures unnecessarily devastated neighborhoods--needlessly pushing families from their communities, pulling children from their schools, and wiping out the lifetime of savings they needed to move on. The [ORGANIZATION] pandemic is likewise hitting these families the hardest again, and the response so far is not equitable or sufficient. But beyond the pandemic response, we must address the long-term structural flaws that produce and perpetuate this inequity.

Therefore, [ORGANIZATION] must take swift and bold action now in creating affordable housing goals that can help return the [ORGANIZATION] to former periods when their activity was much stronger. A key goal of the affordable housing goals must be to help to build toward more racial equity in homeownership. The [ORGANIZATION] should focus explicitly on addressing racial homeownership gaps marginal improvements are insufficient given the [ORGANIZATION] charters that cite the [ORGANIZATION] responsibility to underserved communities and borrowers of color, including to minority census tracts.

Housing counselors have reported instances of borrowers not receiving correct information from servicers, and counselors support will be essential.

Deidentified_paragraph_text: Following the Great Recession, credit tightened making it nearly impossible for buyers who need small balance mortgage loans to be able to receive them. Rising home prices and lack of availability of small dollar mortgage loans have impacted entire cities that have not fully recovered from the housing crisis. Cities like [ORGANIZATION] are credit starved leaving families with only exploitative credit availability. [PERSON] banks often cite a lack of profitability in their decision not to issue small balance mortgages while their investment arms benefit substantially from their vanishing presence in the single-family market. n125 In [ORGANIZATION], nearly 475,000 homes priced below 80,000 were sold, according to [ORGANIZATION] data with only 43 of those financed with a mortgage loan. n126 [PERSON] has worsened this reality as the focus of mortgage originations have shifted to the wealthiest borrowers leaving many credit worthy families with limited mortgage access, which has fallen disproportionately on families of color who typically rely on small balance mortgage loans to purchase a home.

Deidentified_paragraph_text: Manufactured homes are the largest source of unsubsidized, affordable housing in [ORGANIZATION], and have the potential to help address the nations housing affordability crisis. For example, 49 of manufactured housing is affordable for households at or below 50 of [ORGANIZATION], compared to just 26 of all housing. n129 And there is evidence demonstrating that manufactured homes appreciate at levels similar to site-built homes. n130 Because they are less expensive to build, manufactured homes have the potential to greatly expand homeownership opportunities, especially for first-time homebuyers, lower-income households, and people of color.

Deidentified_paragraph_text: Conservatorship has created an historic opportunity for addressing the nations affordable housing crisis and advancing racial equity in housing. As part of the assistance plan for the [ORGANIZATION], the government received stock interests in the [ORGANIZATION], now valued at 48 to 98 billion by [ORGANIZATION]. n165 The value of these assets comes from fees collected from ORG2 loans and that value should remain in the housing market to further affordable housing. In particular, the governments stock interests in the [ORGANIZATION] should be exchanged for a comparable commitment by the [ORGANIZATION] of additional affordable housing measures and a restorative justice housing program that provides targeted down payment and other assistance aimed at closing the racial homeownership gap.

article_source: Congressional Documents and Publications (Federal Information & News Dispatch, Inc.)
Deidentified_paragraph_text: A primary statutory purpose of the [ORGANIZATION] is to advance affordable housing. While the [ORGANIZATION] have maintained their affordable housing programs in [ORGANIZATION], conservatorship has constrained these activities. The [ORGANIZATION] have operated with limited capital at a time when the country needed substantially increased focus on and support of affordable housing from the [ORGANIZATION].

article_source: Congressional Documents and Publications (Federal Information & News Dispatch, Inc.)
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Now they must greatly increase their work to meet the countrys pressing affordable housing needs. [ORGANIZATION] has also seen a national reckoning on the history and continuation of racial discrimination, exclusion, and segregation in our country. Systemic racial barriers exist in all facets of American life, including policing, healthcare, education, environmental, and housing. The housing market profoundly manifests these barriers as discussed throughout this testimony. For the [ORGANIZATION], only a small percentage of their home purchase loans have gone to [ORGANIZATION] homebuyers in [LOCATION], with less than 5 of their loans made to Black families in DATE2. n166 The [ORGANIZATION] charters include a duty to advance fair lending and equity, and much more has to be done by them to advance that national responsibility. The success of the [ORGANIZATION] in conservatorship - in which they have operated as de facto utilities and stabilized the housing market following the [ORGANIZATION] housing crash - establishes that utility oversight is the best structure for the [ORGANIZATION] going forward.

article_source: Congressional Documents and Publications (Federal Information & News Dispatch, Inc.)
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Increased affordable housing support, racial equity programs and utility oversight should be solidified and formalized during conservatorship while the [ORGANIZATION] build up capital. It is critical for these reforms to be implemented before release of the [ORGANIZATION] occurs. While ORG1 reform can be implemented legislatively or by administrative action, enacting ORG1 legislation has proven difficult. Thus, continuing administrative reform is more likely. Central to the reform process is resolution of the [ORGANIZATION] obligations for the aid it received following the [ORGANIZATION] crisis and the ongoing backup support the government will continue to provide in the future. Any amendments to the documents governing these issues will lock in the terms of the [ORGANIZATION] operation and obligations going forward and will be difficult to change. Thus, bolstered affordable housing and racial equity measures and utility oversight must be baked into these steps. n167

Deidentified_paragraph_text: n175 We include within the category of first generation homebuyer those whose parents never owned a home, those whose parents owned a home but lost it to foreclosure, and those who grew up in foster care. Modeled on the first generation homebuyer assistance program of [ORGANIZATION], borrowers would self-certify, as first generation college students currently do. In particular, at least one of the borrowers would certify to the best of their knowledge via affidavit that 1 their parents never owned a home while the borrower was alive 2 their parents owned a home while the borrower was alive but lost it through foreclosure, deed-in-lieu, or short sale or 3 they were in foster care for some period of time as a minor. If the borrower is found to have provided false information, they must return the money without criminal or civil penalties. Applicants may be required to provide their parents full names and most recent addresses.

Deidentified_paragraph_text: These inequities have not been carefully documented but are obvious to all knowledgeable observers. A recent segment on [ORGANIZATION] revealed that 500,000 had been spent per apartment to build a housing project for the homeless in [ORGANIZATION]. n11 This is expensive even by [ORGANIZATION] standards. The median value of owner-occupied houses in the [ORGANIZATION] metro area was 558,000, and the median household income of their occupants was 104,000. So this government program provided apartments to the poorest families that were almost as expensive as the houses occupied by the average homeowner.

Deidentified_paragraph_text: Ensuring that the homeless occupy housing meeting reasonable minimum standards does not require anything like the amount of money spent on these units. Deidentified_paragraph_text: We do not need to build new units to house the homeless. They can be housed in satisfactory existing units at a much lower taxpayer cost. More than 6 percent of the dwelling units in the area were vacant at the time.

Deidentified_paragraph_text: In [ORGANIZATION], [PERSON], where the median value of owner-occupied houses was 249,000, 360,000 per apartment was spent to build another housing project for the homeless. n12 These cases are not anomalies. The [ORGANIZATION] website is filled with photographs of such housing. The desire of the people involved in the current system to provide the best possible housing for their clients is understandable. However, this is not costless. Dollars spent on these high-cost projects are dollars not spent providing housing to more people.

Deidentified_article_title: [ORGANIZATION] on ORG1 Hearing "Oversight of the HUD Inspection Process." Testimony by [ORGANIZATION], [ORGANIZATION] and Public Policy, ORG2
Deidentified_paragraph_text: It is also argued that the failure to renew use agreements on privately owned subsidized projects reduces the number of affordable housing units. If the occupants of these projects are offered portable vouchers, this could not be further from the truth. When use agreements are extended, the only unit that is made affordable to an assisted family living in the project is its own unit. If that family is offered a portable voucher, many units become affordable to the family. Contrary to the arguments of lobbyists for project-based housing assistance, failing to renew use agreements on subsidized housing projects increases rather than decreases the stock of housing that is affordable to low-income households.

article_source: Congressional Documents and Publications (Federal Information & News Dispatch, Inc.)
Deidentified_article_title: [ORGANIZATION] on ORG1 Hearing "Oversight of the HUD Inspection Process." Testimony by [ORGANIZATION], [ORGANIZATION] and Public Policy, ORG2
Deidentified_paragraph_text: By reducing the subsidies sufficiently, we would reach a point where all of the poorest household that ask for assistance would get it. [ORGANIZATION] analyzes the effect of alternative reforms of this type on who is served by the voucher program. n22 This reform would surely reduce evictions and homelessness, although these effects have not been studied.

article_source: Congressional Documents and Publications (Federal Information & News Dispatch, Inc.)
Deidentified_article_title: [ORGANIZATION] on ORG1 Hearing "Oversight of the HUD Inspection Process." Testimony by [ORGANIZATION], [ORGANIZATION] and Public Policy, ORG2
Deidentified_paragraph_text: It is often argued that a shortage of affordable housing calls for subsidizing the construction of new units. This argument is seriously flawed. Almost all people are currently housed. If we think that their housing is too expensive commonly called unaffordable, the cheapest solution is for the government to pay a part of the rent. The housing voucher program does that. This program also ensures that its participants live in units that meet minimum standards. Building new units is a much more expensive solution to the affordability problem.

article_source: Congressional Documents and Publications (Federal Information & News Dispatch, Inc.)
Deidentified_article_title: [ORGANIZATION] on ORG1 Hearing "Oversight of the HUD Inspection Process." Testimony by [ORGANIZATION], [ORGANIZATION] and Public Policy, ORG2
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Furthermore, it is not necessary or desirable to construct new units to house the homeless. The number of people who are homeless is far less than the number of vacant units -- indeed, far less than the number of vacant units renting for less than the median. In the entire country, there are only about 600,000 homeless people on [TIME] and more than 3.6 million vacant units available for rent. Even if all homeless people were single, they could be easily accommodated in vacant existing units, and that would be much less expensive than building new units for them. Furthermore, most of the 600,000 people who are homeless each night already have roofs over their heads in homeless shelters, which are also subsidized. The best provide good housing.
